title.rendered: Create a Campaign Related Lists on Accounts

content.rendered:
Sometimes, you just want to see all the Campaigns for an Account, based on the Contacts associated and their Campaigns. Well, you can, and here is how I setup the Process after the question was posted on the Salesforce Success Community site.

Part 1

  • Create an “Account” field on the Campaign Member Object. The related list on the Account should be called “Campaigns” or something similar
  • Any additional fields you want displayed on the Account’s related list should be created on the campaign member to = the campaign’s field values
  • Update the Account page layout to display the necessary fields from the campaign member’s campaign

Part 2, updating the Account

  • Create a Process with Process Builder that is based on the Campaign Member.

  • Have the following criteria:
    •  Campaign Member’s Contact’s Account <> Account Field
    • ContactId is null = False
    • Contact.AccountId is null = False

  • Set your action to Populate the Account custom field on the Campaign Member with the Accountid from  the Contact, and you’re good to go.

Not so scary right?  Didn’t think so.  Now, don’t forget to create a custom report type for Accounts with/without Campaign Members so you can report on the data.

You can install the package in your sandbox or dev org with the links below.  The package includes the process, campaign member account field, and a custom report type for Accounts w/without Campaigns.

Find it on the AppExchange Here

Sandbox: https://test.salesforce.com/packaging/installPackage.apexp?p0=04to00000007Mh5
Dev Org: https://login.salesforce.com/packaging/installPackage.apexp?p0=04to00000007Mh5

jetpack-related-posts.title: Community Sharing Part 3: Channel Programs
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: We have talked about Sharing Sets, Page Visibility and Guests, now we are going a bit of a different directions, how to take those pages and take the users and find out how to make then into different groups for audiences, folders, sharing groups, managing resources, and standard partner categories…

jetpack-related-posts.title: Named Account Model Implementation: Part 1 – Before We Begin
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Implementation of a Named Account Model is a large undertaking. It can be stressful for even the most experienced admin, but it doesn't have to be. This post reviews the concept of what a named account model is and high level requirements before planning your project.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Named Account Implementation Part 2 – Building Your List
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: After planning your implementation, the next step is to build your list. Read Part 2 to learn how to select the right companies for your named account list for the best results.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Move Related Lists On Lead Convert
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: It's not magic, it's Process Builder! Learn how you can move records related to Leads over to the Contact on Lead conversion, with a simple process.

img.alt_text: Move Related Lists On Lead Convert

jetpack-related-posts.title: Community Sharing Part 1: Sharing Sets – Your First Step in Sharing
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Sharing Sets are an amazing superpower that comes with your Communities. They are a way to share with Community License types and Community users. Keep in mind, this type of security and sharing is only available for your community users, it is not available to share with internal users.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Tracking Competitors
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: How are you tracking your competitors in Salesforce? Are you? If you aren’t, you need to. Not you should, you must. If you already are tracking competitors by opportunity, is it working for you? Are you getting the value you want? If not, it is time for a change. If…
